questions.question: What is the length of the eustachian tube?
Which of the following is false regarding the eustachian tube?

options.C: Outer 1/3rd is bony and inner 2/3rd is cartilaginous

questions.explanation: Parts of the Eustachian tubeTensor tympaniTensor veli palatiniLevator veli palatiniSalpingopharyngeusOMARROWBony partIsthmusCartilaginouspartPharyngealend244The eustachian tube also called the auditory or pharyngotympanic tube connects the nasopharynxwith the tympanic cavity.It is 36 mm long in adults and is divided into two parts:• Bony part - forms the outer one-third of the tube as it is located near the middle ear and is 12mm in size.• Fibrocartilaginous part - forms the inner two-third as it is located near the nasopharynx and is24 mm in size.In the middle ear it opens in the anterior wall and in the nasopharynx it opens 1-1.25 cm posteriorto the posterior end of the inferior turbinate.Parts of the Eustachian tubeTensor tympaniTensor veli palatiniLevator veli palatiniSalpingopharyngeusOMARROWBony partIsthmusCartilaginouspartPharyngealend

questions.question: Which of the following is the narrowest part of the eustachian tube?
questions.explanation: The narrowest part of the eustachian tube is the isthmus. It is the junction of the bony andcartilaginous parts.Infundibulum is not a part of eustachian tube.245Parts of the Eustachian tubeTensor tympaniTensor veli palatiniLevator veli palatiniSalpingopharyngeusOMARROWBony partIsthmusCartilaginouspartPharyngealend

questions.question: You are an intern asking a patient to perform a Valsalva maneuver for the relief of an ear block. Which of the following structures helps in opening the Eustachian tube during this maneuver?
questions.explanation: Tensor veli palatini helps in opening the Eustachian tube during the Valsalva maneuver. It is closed at rest and opens intermittently during swallowing, yawning, and sneezing. Opening of the tube: The medial fibers of the tensor veli palatini are attached to the lateral lamina of the tube and contract to open the tubal lumen. It is also called the dilator tubae muscle. Accessory muscles for opening are levator veli palatini and salpingopharyngeus. Closure of the tube: It is mainly due to the elastic recoil of the cartilage aided by the high degree of elastin on the roof. Ostmann's pad of fat helps to keep the tube closed.

questions.question: Which of the following supplies the tensor veli palatini muscle?
questions.explanation: The mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve supplies the tensor veli palatini which opens theEustachian tube.Muscles of the Eustachian tube:Sensory & parasympathetic supply to ET: Glossopharyngeal NerveMuscleNerve supplyActionTensor veli palatine/ Dilator tubaeMandibular branch of trigeminal nerveOpens the tubeLevator veli palatinePharyngeal plexusOpens & lifts the tubeSalpingopharyngeusPharyngeal plexusOpens the tube

questions.question: A child presented with recurrent attacks of acute otitis media. Which of the followingproperties of the eustachian tube predisposes to this?
questions.explanation: The Eustachian tube in children is wider, shorter (13-18mm), and more horizontal. Thecartilaginous part is flaccid due to less elastin.The above differences make children more prone to retrograde reflux of nasopharyngealsecretions and middle ear infections. In infants along with the secretions, the milk also refluxesback while feeding in the supine position.

questions.question: Which of the following is a cause for functional eustachian tube obstruction?
questions.explanation: 247Cleft palate is a cause for functional Eustachian tube (ET) obstruction.Eustachian tube obstruction can be mechanical, functional or both. Mechanical obstruction canresult from intrinsic causes such as inflammation or allergy or extrinsic causes such as tumour oradenoids. Functional obstruction is caused by collapse of the tube due to increased cartilagecompliance or failure of active tubal opening mechanism due to poor function of tensor velipalatini.In the cleft palate, the obstruction is due to high elastin content at torus tubaris and the poorfunction of tensor veli palatini.

questions.question: You are evaluating the patency and function of the Eustachian tube in a patient with a rightearache and ear block. Which of the following test you will not do?
questions.explanation: Stenger test is not used for the assessment of patency or function of the eustachian tube. It is usedto detect malingering of hearing loss.Tests of Eustachian tube patency:• Pneumatic otoscopy• Nasopharyngoscopy•• Valsalva manoeuvre• ET catheterization• Politzer test.Tests of Eustachian tube function:• Toynbee's test•Tympanometry•Saccharine/dye tests in perforated ears•Sonotubometry.

questions.question: An ENT resident is performing the following maneuver in a patient as shown in the image.Which of the following is false regarding the same?

options.A: It builds negative pressure in the nasopharynx

questions.explanation: The given image depicts the Valsalva manoeuvre and it builds up positive pressure in thenasopharynx and not negative pressure.In this test, the patient is asked to close the mouth and nostrils and blow. This produces positivepressure within the nasopharynx which opens the patent eustachian tube and is confirmed by thetympanic membrane bulge via otoscopy.It is used to assess the Eustachian tube patency and to auto-inflate the middle ear.It is contraindicated in:•Atrophic tympanic membrane as it might get ruptured.•URTI as the infection can spread into the middle ear.248

questions.question: An otolaryngologist is performing the following procedure in a patient. Which of thefollowing is true about this procedure?241

options.D: Used to instill medications into middle ear

questions.explanation: The procedure depicted in the image is Eustachian tube (ET) catheterization and it uses Politzer'sbag and an ET catheter.The catheter is passed along the nasal floor and manoeuvred into the ET opening and the bag isinsufflated. The outward movement of the tympanic membrane is then noted with an otoscope.It is an unsafe and outdated ET function test. It can lead to complications like TM rupture,scarring of ET, epistaxis, spread of nasal/pharyngeal infection to the middle ear.In the methylene blue dye test, the dye is instilled into the middle ear and the time taken by it tostain the pharynx is noted.Politzer test is a non-invasive alternative for this and works on the same principle. It uses a nasalolive instead of a catheter and is useful in children who can't perform the Valsalva or Toynbeetest.

questions.question: A 3-year-old child was brought to the OPD with fever, earache, and poor feeding after anepisode of URTI. You suspect this as acute suppurative otitis media due to an eustachian tubedefect. Which is the most accurate test to detect this?
questions.explanation: Tympanometry is the most accurate test to assess eustachian tube (ET) dysfunction. It is anobjective measure of ET function and does not rely on patient cooperation.In this test, the movement of TM is visualized to the variation in external canal pressure. Thedisadvantage is middle ear pathologies can overshadow ET function.

questions.question: A middle-aged retropositive woman presented with complaints of hearing her own voice andbreath sounds with ear fullness. She has lost significant weight in the past 6 months. What isthe likely diagnosis in this case?

options.B: Superior canal dehiscence syndromePatulous eustachian tube242d) Blocked eustachian tubeQuestion 13:For a patient to get barotraumatic otitis media, what is the critical level of the atmosphericpressure required?a) 30 mmHgb) 60 mmHg

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario describes autophony which is seen patulous eustachian tube.Autophony is a symptom where the patient hears his own voice and breath sounds.Patulous eustachian tube is usually idiopathic where the tube is abnormally patent. But it is alsoseen in rapid weight loss, pregnancy especially the third trimester and patients with multiplesclerosis.Treatment includes weight gain, administration of potassium iodide solution. In long-standingcases, specific treatment could include cauterization of tubes or insertion of the grommet.Option A: In HIV-related psychosis, there will be persecutory delusion, hallucination, and no earfullness.Option B: The autophony of superior canal dehiscence syndrome usually involves hearing theirown voice but not their breathing when compared with patients who have patulous eustachiantube.Option D: Patient with blocked eustachian tube does not present with autophony.249

questions.question: Which of the following activities is least likely to cause otitic barotrauma?
questions.explanation: A pilot performing take-off (i.e. rapid ascent in the air) is least likely to cause otitic barotraumacompared to other options.The usual causes for otitic barotrauma are• Rapid descent during air travel (skydiver)•Underwater diving (scuba diving)• Compression in a pressure chamber (hyperbaric oxygen therapy).

questions.question: Which of the following is not a feature of otitic barotrauma?
questions.explanation: Hyperacusis is not a feature of otitic barotrauma.Otitic barotrauma is a non-suppurative condition resulting from the failure of the eustachian tubeto maintain middle ear pressure at ambient atmospheric level. It is usually caused by rapiddescent during air flight, underwater diving or compression in the pressure chamber.•Severe earache, deafness, and tinnitus are common complaints.• The TM appears retracted and congested. It can get ruptured in severe cases.• The middle ear may show air bubbles or hemorrhagic effusion.•Hearing loss is usually conductive.•Rarely, there is a rupture of labyrinthine membranes causing vertigo and sensorineural hearingloss.250
